title: Fukuoka PayPay Dome
text:
The is a <a href="baseball%20field">baseball field</a>, located in <a href="Ch%C5%AB%C5%8D-ku%2C%20Fukuoka">Chūō-ku</a>, <a href="Fukuoka">Fukuoka</a>, Japan. Built in 1993, the stadium was originally named and has the capacity of 38,585 seats. With a diameter of 216 meters, the Fukuoka PayPay Dome is the world's largest geodesic dome. This is Japan's first stadium built with a <a href="retractable%20roof">retractable roof</a>. In 2005, <a href="Yahoo%21%20JAPAN">Yahoo! JAPAN</a>, one of <a href="SoftBank">SoftBank</a>'s <a href="subsidiary">subsidiaries</a>, acquired the stadium's <a href="naming%20rights">naming rights</a>, and thus renamed it or abbreviated as , In January 2013, it was renamed to . Yafuoku is the abbreviation for <a href="Yahoo%21%20Auctions">Yahoo! Auctions</a> in Japan. On October 30, 2019, it was announced that the stadium was going to be named Fukuoka PayPay Dome, in reference to the payment system <a href="PayPay">PayPay</a> owned by Softbank (50%) and Yahoo Japan (25%), from February 29, 2020.
History.
Fukuoka Dome is the home stadium of <a href="Fukuoka%20SoftBank%20Hawks">Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks</a> and, together with <a href="Hilton%20Hotel">Hilton</a> Fukuoka Sea Hawk Hotel, is part of the Hawks Town entertainment complex. It is located near <a href="Sawara-ku%2C%20Fukuoka">Momochi Beach</a>, about 15 minutes walk from <a href="T%C5%8Djinmachi%20Station">Tojinmachi</a> <a href="Fukuoka%20City%20Subway">subway</a> station.
In 2006, the stadium received an upgrade to its mono-color main scoreboard "Hawks Vision." Sharing the same nickname as its predecessor and measured at 10 m (32.76 ft) high and 53 m (173.86 ft) wide, it was one of the largest high-definition electronic scoreboards at the time, equivalent to a 2,123-inch wide-screen display. In 2010, with further addition of two 5.7 m (120.65 ft) × 33 m (108.27 ft) displays, the stadium boasted the largest total viewing area of HD display in all baseball stadia (total area 905.2sqm or 9,743.49sqft).
The Fukuoka Dome has hosted one game in each <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Japan%20All-Star%20Series">Major League Baseball Japan All-Star Series</a> since its creation, including the final game of the 2006 series, where Japan was swept for the first time in the history of the event.
In the TV series "<a href="Extreme%20Engineering">Extreme Engineering</a>", Danny Forster makes a reference to the Fukuoka Dome, saying it was said to have a "floating" field. (An indoor baseball stadium in Japan which actually has a floating field is <a href="Sapporo%20Dome">Sapporo Dome</a>, which also hosts <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> games for <a href="Consadole%20Sapporo">Consadole Sapporo</a>, a <a href="J.%20League">J. League</a> club. However, this stadium does not have such a field.) In 2009, the older <a href="AstroTurf">AstroTurf</a> field was replaced with the now more common <a href="FieldTurf">FieldTurf</a> brand surface to reduce injuries; the Hawks players had seen far more injuries than any other team in Japan.
Notable Events.
NPB.
On May 18, 1994, <a href="Hiromi%20Makihara">Hiromi Makihara</a> of the <a href="Yomiuri%20Giants">Yomiuri Giants</a> threw a <a href="Perfect%20game%20%28baseball%29">perfect game</a> against <a href="Hiroshima%20Toyo%20Carp">Hiroshima Toyo Carp</a> as the Giants won 6–0. Makihara's first Perfect-game at Fukuoka Dome is of special note as it being the only one thrown there, as well as the last one in the NPB(15th overall), through the 2020 season.
Concerts.
<a href="Michael%20Jackson">Michael Jackson</a> performed at the stadium four times during his solo career. The first two times, Jackson performed two sold-out concerts during his "<a href="Dangerous%20World%20Tour">Dangerous World Tour</a>", on September 10 & 11, 1993, for a total audience of 70,000 fans (35,000 per show). The second and last two times were in 1996, during his subsequent tour, "<a href="HIStory%20World%20Tour">HIStory World Tour</a>", on December 26 and 28, also on two sold-out concerts for 80,000 people (40,000 fans per show).
<a href="Whitney%20Houston">Whitney Houston</a> performed at the stadium on September 22, 1993 during <a href="The%20Bodyguard%20World%20Tour">The Bodyguard World Tour</a>.
<a href="Madonna%20%28entertainer%29">Madonna</a> performed three times at the stadium. The shows happened on 7, 8, and 9 December 1993 during <a href="The%20Girlie%20Show%20World%20Tour">The Girlie Show World Tour</a>.
The stadium also hosted <a href="Frank%20Sinatra">Frank Sinatra</a>'s final public concerts on 19 and 20 December 1994.
The <a href="Rolling%20Stones">Rolling Stones</a> played two concerts at the dome during their <a href="Voodoo%20Lounge%20Tour">Voodoo Lounge Tour</a> on 22 and 23 March 1995.
<a href="Bon%20Jovi">Bon Jovi</a> played a concert at the dome on May 13, 1995 during their <a href="These%20Days%20Tour">These Days Tour</a>.
On September 18 and 19, 2000, the stadium hosted <a href="L%27Arc~en~Ciel">L'Arc~en~Ciel</a> as part of their "TOUR 2000 REAL".
<a href="Mariko%20Shinoda">Mariko Shinoda</a> held her graduation concert at the stadium on July 21st, 2013 as part of the AKB48 5 Big Dome Concert Tour, "AKB48 2013 Manatsu no Dome Tour ~Mada mada, Yaranakya Ikenai koto ga aru~ (AKB48・2013真夏のドームツアー ～まだまだ、やらなきゃいけないことがある～)" that summer.
<a href="Super%20Junior">Super Junior</a> performed their <a href="Super%20Show%206">Super Show 6</a> at the stadium on 20 December 2014 as part of their sixth world tour, with a sold-out crowd of 47,874 people.
<a href="Blackpink">Blackpink</a> had a sold-out concert at the stadium on 22 February 2020 as part of their In Your Area Tour.
<a href="Perfume%20%28Japanese%20band%29">Perfume</a> performed a show at the stadium for their First Nationwide Major Dome tour, 'P Cubed'.
